titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Allen J. Kone collection of Brooklyn postcards 2016.014
titlestmt.author: Katherine Palm

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-05-18 19:39:59 +0000.

did.unittitle: Allen J. Kone collection of Brooklyn postcards
did.abstract: The collection comprises approximately 840 photographic and picture postcards collected by Allen J. Kone that relate to Brooklyn, chiefly documenting the Brooklyn Bridge and the Downtown Brooklyn, Brooklyn Heights, Cobble Hill, and Fort Greene neighborhoods of Brooklyn. Within these neighborhoods institutions such as charities, schools, civic buildings, and churches are represented, as well as businesses and leisure locations such as clubs, restaurants, and theaters. The bulk of the collection dates from the early twentieth century. Some cards are postmarked and/or stamped and have handwritten messages.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The postcards were removed from two binders that originally housed the collection and placed in an archival box.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection's organization reflects Kone's system of arrangement. One section is dedicated to postcards relating to the Brooklyn Bridge and the rest of the collection is loosely arranged by geographical location.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection comprises approximately 840 photographic and picture postcards collected by Allen J. Kone that relate to Brooklyn, chiefly documenting the Downtown Brooklyn, Brooklyn Heights, Cobble Hill, and Fort Greene neighborhoods of Brooklyn. Within these neighborhoods institutions such as charities, schools, civic buildings, and churches are represented, as well as businesses and leisure locations such as clubs, restaurants, and theaters. Approximately one fifth of the collection consists of postcards relating to the Brooklyn Bridge. The collection also contains many postcards of various buildings in the Borough Hall area. Other highlights of the collection include many postcards of the Hotel St. George, the Hotel Bossert, and postcards of the Young Men's Christian Association and Young Women's Christian Association. The bulk of the collection dates from the early twentieth century. Some cards are postmarked and/or stamped and have handwritten messages.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The copyright status of this collection has not been evaluated. Please consult library staff for more information.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Allen J. Kone collection of Brooklyn postcards, 2016.014, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Allen J. Kone is a retired attorney and longtime resident of Brooklyn, New York who collected Brooklyn view cards and post cards for over 30 years. His chief collecting interests were in the Brooklyn Bridge and Downtown Brooklyn, including the surrounding "brownstone neighborhoods" such as the Brooklyn Heights, Cobble Hill, and Fort Greene neighborhoods of Brooklyn.
